prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0345+0056 and HE0351+0240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of the CO(1-0) emission lines across the AGN host galaxies at 3" resolution. Furthermore, we also use the 3 remaining base bands in continuum mode to potentially detect the AGN radio continuum at the galaxy centre as ancillary science and increasing the return of the observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target one spectral window centered on the redshifted CO(1-0) line in band 3. Since the expected line width across the galaxy can vary between 20-100km/s we choose a spectral bandwidth of 1.1MHz (3km/s) to reduce the data rate and still allow to cover the narrowest line widths by 5 resolution elements.
We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (~90km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any radio AGN continuum at the central beam.

We want to achieve a comparable spatial resolution compared to our 1-1.5" seeing limited optical IFU data. We performed ALMA OST simulations based on the MUSE IFU Halpha maps to compare angular resolutions of 1.2", 2" and 3" (see proposal). We then decided for 3" in this case as optimal compromise between resolution and depth according to the expected spatial substructure in the CO(1-0) emission. The largest angular scale of the source is determined by the minor axis of the host galaxies.

Our sensitivity calculation is based on integrated CO(1-0) line flux measurements with the IRAM 30m telescope for the galaxy. From existing MUSE data we reconstruct Halpha maps that represent ongoing sites of star formation. We distribute the integrated CO(1-0)flux according to the Halpha maps to take into account the expected substructure. We then assume a line width of 100km/s to compute the peak flux density from the integrated line flux per 3" beam corresponding to 1.5kpc resolution for the galaxy at that redshift. A bandwidth of 6MHz corresponds to 20km/s resolution elements to be able to split up the line into at least 5 elements. We set the sensitivity such that we are able to detect the CO emission in knots far away from the galaxy center at 5sigma per beam. We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 20-100km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. We will simply adapt the bandwidth accordingly. At that sensitivity we will test whether we actually can detect any radio continuum of the AGN in the central beam. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 2.5mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0119-0118
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of the CO(1-0) emission lines across the AGN host galaxies at 1.2" resolution. Furthermore, we also use the 3 remaining base bands in continuum mode to potentially detect the AGN radio continuum at the galaxy centre as ancillary science and increasing the return of the observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target one spectral window centered on the redshifted CO(1-0) line in band 3. Since the expected line width across the galaxy can vary between 20-100km/s we choose a spectral bandwidth of 1.1MHz (3.1km/s) to reduce the data rate and still allow to cover the narrowest line widths by 5 resolution elements.
We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (~90km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any radio AGN continuum at the central beam.

From existing MUSE data we reconstruct Halpha maps that represent ongoing sites of star formation. We distribute the integrated CO(1-0)flux according to the Halpha maps to take into account the expected substructure. We then assume a line width of 50km/s to compute the peak flux density from the integrated line flux per 1.2" beam corresponding to 1kpc resolution for the galaxy at that redshift. A bandwidth of 3MHz corresponds to 10km/s resolution elements to be able to split up the line into at least 5 elements. We set the sensitivity such that we are able to detect the CO emission in knots far away from the galaxy center at 5sigma per beam. We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 20-100km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 4.6mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 20-100km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. We will simply adapt the bandwidth accordingly. At that sensitivity we will test whether we actually can detect any radio continuum of the AGN in the central beam. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 14.2mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0429-0247
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of the CO(1-0) emission lines across the AGN host galaxies at 3" resolution. Furthermore, we also use the 3 remaining base bands in continuum mode to potentially detect the AGN radio continuum at the galaxy centre as ancillary science and increasing the return of the observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target one spectral window centered on the redshifted CO(1-0) line in band 3. Since the expected line width across the galaxy can vary between 20-100km/s we choose a spectral bandwidth of 1.1MHz (3km/s) to reduce the data rate and still allow to cover the narrowest line widths by 5 resolution elements.
We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (~90km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any radio AGN continuum at the central beam.

We want to achieve a comparable spatial resolution compared to our 1-1.5" seeing limited optical IFU data. We performed ALMA OST simulations based on the MUSE IFU Halpha maps to compare angular resolutions of 1.2", 2" and 3" (see proposal). We then decided for 3" in this case as optimal compromise between resolution and depth according to the expected spatial substructure in the CO(1-0) emission. The largest angular scale of the source is determined by the minor axis of the host galaxies.

Our sensitivity calculation is based on integrated CO(1-0) line flux measurements with the IRAM 30m telescope for the galaxy. From existing MUSE data we reconstruct Halpha maps that represent ongoing sites of star formation. We distribute the integrated CO(1-0)flux according to the Halpha maps to take into account the expected substructure. We then assume a line width of 100km/s to compute the peak flux density from the integrated line flux per 3" beam corresponding to 2kpc resolution for the galaxy at that redshift. A bandwidth of 6MHz corresponds to 20km/s resolution elements to be able to split up the line into at least 5 elements. We set the sensitivity such that we are able to detect the CO emission in knots far away from the galaxy center at 5sigma per beam. We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 30-150km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. We will simply adapt the bandwidth accordingly. At that sensitivity we will test whether we actually can detect any radio continuum of the AGN in the central beam. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 2.5mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE1011-0403
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of the CO(1-0) emission lines across the AGN host galaxies at 1.2" resolution. Furthermore, we also use the 3 remaining base bands in continuum mode to potentially detect the AGN radio continuum at the galaxy centre as ancillary science and increasing the return of the observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target one spectral window centered on the redshifted CO(1-0) line in band 3. Since the expected line width across the galaxy can vary between 20-100km/s we choose a spectral bandwidth of 1.1MHz (3km/s) to reduce the data rate and still allow to cover the narrowest line widths by 5 resolution elements.
We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (~90km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any radio AGN continuum at the central beam.

We want to achieve a comparable spatial resolution compared to our 1-1.5" seeing limited optical IFU data. We performed ALMA OST simulations based on the MUSE IFU Halpha maps to compare angular resolutions of 1.2", 2" and 3" (see proposal). We then decided for 1.2" in this case as optimal compromise between resolution and depth according to the expected spatial substructure in the CO(1-0) emission. The largest angular scale of the source is determined by the minor axis of the host galaxies.

Our sensitivity calculation is based on integrated CO(1-0) line flux measurements with the IRAM 30m telescope for the galaxy. From existing MUSE data we reconstruct Halpha maps that represent ongoing sites of star formation. We distribute the integrated CO(1-0)flux according to the Halpha maps to take into account the expected substructure. We then assume a line width of 50km/s to compute the peak flux density from the integrated line flux per 1.2" beam corresponding to 1kpc resolution for the galaxy at that redshift. A bandwidth of 3MHz corresponds to 10km/s resolution elements to be able to split up the line into at least 5 elements. We set the sensitivity such that we are able to detect the CO emission in knots far away from the galaxy center at 5sigma per beam. We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 20-100km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. We will simply adapt the bandwidth accordingly. At that sensitivity we will test whether we actually can detect any radio continuum of the AGN in the central beam. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 1.0mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE0934+0119
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of the CO(1-0) emission lines across the AGN host galaxies at 3" resolution. Furthermore, we also use the 3 remaining base bands in continuum mode to potentially detect the AGN radio continuum at the galaxy centre as ancillary science and increasing the return of the observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We target one spectral window centered on the redshifted CO(1-0) line in band 3. Since the expected line width across the galaxy can vary between 20-100km/s we choose a spectral bandwidth of 1.1MHz (3km/s) to reduce the data rate and still allow to cover the narrowest line widths by 5 resolution elements.
We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (~90km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any radio AGN continuum at the central beam.

We want to achieve a comparable spatial resolution compared to our 1-1.5" seeing limited optical IFU data. We performed ALMA OST simulations based on the MUSE IFU Halpha maps to compare angular resolutions of 1.2", 2" and 3" (see proposal). We then decided for 3" in this case as optimal compromise between resolution and depth according to the expected spatial substructure in the CO(1-0) emission. The largest angular scale of the source is determined by the minor axis of the host galaxies.

Our sensitivity calculation is based on integrated CO(1-0) line flux measurements with the IRAM 30m telescope for the galaxy. From existing MUSE data we reconstruct Halpha maps that represent ongoing sites of star formation. We distribute the integrated CO(1-0)flux according to the Halpha maps to take into account the expected substructure. We then assume a line width of 100km/s to compute the peak flux density from the integrated line flux per 3" beam corresponding to 2.5kpc resolution for the galaxy at that redshift. A bandwidth of 6MHz corresponds to 20km/s resolution elements to be able to split up the line into at least 5 elements. We set the sensitivity such that we are able to detect the CO emission in knots far away from the galaxy center at 5sigma per beam. We have verified our sensitivity calculation with ALMA OST simulations shown in the proposal. Note that the line width can vary between 20-100km/s which does not change the required sensitivity as it changes the peak flux density for a given integrated line flux. We will simply adapt the bandwidth accordingly. At that sensitivity we will test whether we actually can detect any radio continuum of the AGN in the central beam. It is hard to predict the continuum flux so we provide just a rough estimate assuming that all the known radio 1.4GHz flux of 2.5mJy is point-like with a radio spectral slope of -0.8. In particular the radio spectral index is not know and can vary significantly.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(1-0) line mapping with ALMA for a sample of 17 nearby luminous AGN host galaxies. Those observation are part of our ongoing Close AGN Reference Survey (CARS) building up a spatially-resolved multi-wavelength legacy data set for the community. Half of the AGN were already observed with the wide-field optical IFU MUSE at the VLT, yielding an unprecedented view on the properties of the stellar population, ionized gas and kinematics for these galaxies. We now want to resolve the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas with spatial resolution of 1"-3" to understand the life cycle of gas in these luminous AGN host galaxies with combined power of ALMA and MUSE focussing on the following science goals: 1) probe the conditions for star formation as a function of radius in terms of gas depletion time and Kennicutt-Schmidt relation and ompare the cold gas distribution with control samples of non-AGN galaxies from the CALIFA/EDGE survey, 2) detect massive molecular outflows and compare them to ionized gas outflows, and 3) test whether the apparent relation between AGN luminosity and circumnuclear/total SFR is driven by the radial gas density distribution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00679.S, PI: B. Husemann, 'Mapping high density gas in circumnuclear discs and outflows around nearby luminous AGN'
